entry.title: Re: Multi-Tenant Audit Logging Fails for Subscriber Tenan...
entry.content:
Hello @agustino 

Thanks for the additional context. I’ve actually come across this exact scenario in one of my recent CAP projects. When using centralized audit logging in the provider tenant, the key is not to inject the x-zid header manually or rely on CAP’s default behaviour to do so. The log2restv2 logger attempts by default to obtain a token for the subscriber tenant and this fails because the Audit Log Service is not bound there.

What we did was to ensure we logged in with the provider tenant’s credentials. I also suggest removing remove any x-zid header or override the logger context, if necessary, In your CAP logic. Then, make use of the tenant (subscriberID) API on the audit logger just for tagging the event with the right subscriber, but let the token still come from the provider’s XSUAA. By doing that, you will be complying with SAP’s recommendation for centralized logging events are tagged per tenant, but authorization and logging all route through the provider’s service binding.

Hope this provides the desired solution.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAPFPAYM not triggered automatically after F110 / Man...
entry.content:
The fact that your payment run completes successfully but the DME file is not automatically generated points to a missing or misconfigured link in the Printout/Data Medium setup.

Go to transaction FBZP → Payment Methods in Company Code, select your payment method, in the Printout/Data Medium tab, ensure Program SAPFPAYM is assigned (not just RFFOAVIS_FPAYM). Assign a variant for SAPFPAYM that includes Payment run date and ID, Output control settings (e.g., “Data Medium Exchange” checked). If SAPFPAYM is not listed, you may need to manually add it via customizing or use OBPM4 to define variants.

Use transaction OBPM4 to assign the correct variant for SAPFPAYM. Create or adjust the variant used for your payment method. Ensure the variant includes Payment run date and ID as dynamic parameters, Output to File System or TemSe as needed, Data Medium Exchange checkbox enabled.  Check SAP Note 984462 which explains how SAPFPAYM_SCHEDULE uses OBPM4 variants to trigger SAPFPAYM automatically.

In F110, before executing the payment run go to the Printout/Data Medium tab, Ensure the correct variant for SAPFPAYM is selected. Check the box for “Start Immediately” to trigger the print program.

Troubleshooting tips

entry.title: Re: How to add fields to LSMW Standard Batch Input
entry.content:
Hi @ABS21 

Thank you for your follow-up.

To your first question, it's not possible to add custom fields via the IBIPBDCD structure in standard LSMW for object. The reason behind this is, IBIPBDCD is designed to support a fixed set of SAP-delivered fields for batch input purposes and cannot be extended to include custom fields or Z-fields. You would require a custom development to achieve this.

For your second question, please note, fields from the 'Service Specification' screen, such as Net Price, are not supported by standard LSMW for task lists. The standard batch input object doesn't navigate into that screen, which is why the Net Price remains empty after upload. You have the possibility to Create a custom LSMW recording of transaction IA01/IA11 that includes the required screens and fields. This allows screen-by-screen control but might be sensitive to layout changes and screen sequence.

If you want to consider direct table updates, only do so if absolutely necessary and if your organization allows it but inconsistencies might happen.

Unfortunately, LSMW in its standard form is limited when it comes to advanced UI scenarios like Service Specifications.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
entry.content:
This second post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and the SAP Fiori launchpad which are now generally available. It covers Joule and many AI-assisted UX innovations, new collaboration capabilities as well as improvements in details. The next post will cover additional innovations available to customers for beta testing.

Users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can query SAP Analytics Cloud directly via Joule. Read about this and more in the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

This post gives an overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition UX innovations in these areas:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency
  • My Home
  • AI-Assisted UX Features
  • Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams
  • UX Improvements in Details

Many of the UX improvements in details are enabled by our UI framework (SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements) and hence also available to customers and partners developing their own applications. Note however that the enabled AI-assisted features are only available for extensions built directly on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.

Below you’ll see those AI innovations with largest impact on user experience, but you can get a more comprehensive overview of the latest AI innovations in these blog posts:

  • Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release.
  • Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 (covering the AI-assisted features enabled by our UI framework).

 

SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency

We have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we’ll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations, and some updates for launchpad administrators:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design
  • Update for administrators

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 1. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry “All Spaces” at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the “Favourite App” eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder “Insights” for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar – need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case “S/4HANA Cloud” as you can see at the top of Figure 1. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (i.e. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments – in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature “/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE”, which is planned to become available mid-August 2025.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 2 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the “Sign Out” option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

Figure 2: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group “Last Month”, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a “more” link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 2  fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and provides simplier interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by “Today”, “Yesterday”, “Last Week”, “Last Month”. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 3 shows two examples – one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing “search”. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Hiding of Empty Spaces and Pages

Empty Spaces and Pages are now automatically hidden from users. Until now this was an option which administrators needed to switch on, now it is on by default.

You might be asking how a space or page could be empty? The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user’s authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty.

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps “Manage Launchpad Spaces” and “Manage Launchpad Pages” distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab “Customer-Created”, the others in the tab “Predefined”.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as “Customer-Created” in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became “Predefined” there, i.e. it was not listed under “Customer-Created” despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app “Manage Launchpad Pages”, the tabs are called “Pages” and “Page Templates”, as shown in Figure 4. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 4: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for “Pages” and “Page Templates”. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

For more information about the visual updates, and what’s new, check out:

  • Blog post: Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System updates.
  • What’s New: SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

My Home

My Home is proving very popular with users, and we hope to make it even more so with the innovations in the 2508 release:

  • The salutation bar, welcoming users and providing interesting options.
  • Recap – summarizing what changed since you last logged on.
  • Manage News application for customer-specific news.
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insights cards
    (this is covered in the next section AI-Assisted UX Innovations)

We are also providing two new features for beta-testing, AI-assisted smart personalization for applications and AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home, which I will showcase in part 3 in this series of blog posts.

Salutation Bar in My Home

The new salutation bar shown in Figure 5 welcomes users to the system, and gives them direct access to My Home settings as well as to the new Recap feature explained below. Optionally, you can set the system up to let business users see what’s next on their calendar. (Not shown in Figure 5. Use communication arrangement SAP_COM_0887 to set enable it).

Figure 5: The new salutation bar in My Home, showing the welcome text “Hi Barbara, Great to see you again!” and the beta AI option “Add Content”, plus the options “Recap” and “My Home Settings”. Alt Text: Image shows My Home with a new dark. Blue bar just below the header, with today’s date top left, below which in larger font “Hi Barbara, Great to see you again!” is written. On the right of the bar three buttons are shown: the AI button “Add Content”, “Recap”, and “My Home Settings”.

Recap

With recap, you can get a quick overview of what has changed on My Home since you last logged on: new or updated tasks, situations and insight cards. This saves you a lot of time, since you don’t have to scan everything manually, and ensures that you are all caught up quickly – and don’t miss any important changes. What is great about it is that it is visual, showing before and after images of insight cards – you can see an example in Figure 6, or watch it in action in this video:

  • Video: Recap Feature of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (0:55 min.)

Figure 6: Recap in My Home, showing a change in an insight card, where one additional quotation has expired, and one additional quotation will expire after a week. Alt Text: a popover on top of My Home, with a “Summary” section on the left containing three items “Tasks”, “Situations”, and “Cards”, with “Cards” selected. The right shows two tabs, “Changed (3)” (selected) and “Removed (2)”, below which a card marked “old” with a horizontal bar chart is shown on the left, and the same card with updated data marked “new” on the right.

Manage News Application

I’m glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 7 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users or roles.

Figure 7: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status “published” and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?.
  • My Home documentation.

 

AI-Assisted User Experience

When AI is embedded directly into the application UI to give users a better user experience, as opposed to being accessed via the Joule window, we talk about “AI-Assisted User Experience”.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, we distinguish between AI base features and premium features:

  • Base features are free of charge, and only require that the customer signs the SAP AI Terms, which can be done via this link.
  • Premium features require SAP AI Units to be in place. Those listed here also require Joule Premium for Financial Management. Customers can activate this via SAP for Me -> Portfolio & Products -> Business AI.

The following are now generally available as base features:

  • AI-assisted enterprise search (which was in beta testing with the 2502 release). See below for more details.
  • AI-assisted easy filter.
  • AI-assisted smart summarization.

The latter two were generally available under limited promotion with the 2502 release, now they are generally available out of the box – no need to sign up to the limited promotion. To find out more about these two, look at my blog post:

  • SAP UX Q1/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The following premium feature is now generally available:

  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards.
    See below for more details.

AI-Assisted Enterprise Search

You can now use natural language in the search field available at the top of every screen in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, making it even easier to benefit from powerful enterprise search capabilities. With enterprise search, you can find the information you need directly, without having to specify the name of the application – as you can see in Figure 8. This is available out of the box as a base feature.

Figure 8: AI-assisted enterprise search, showing how you can easily find business data directly using natural language. Alt Text: ALT Text: A short video showing how a user can enter in the search field in the shell header bar “Show me all sales orders with net value greater than 5000 eur” and get a corresponding list sales orders. The user than adds the text “that are in process” resulting in a list with fewer results.

Watch the full video:

  • Video:  AI-Assisted Enterprise Search in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  (0:48 min.)

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insight Cards

With this premium feature, you can now use natural language to add an insight card to My Home. You just have to describe what information you want to see on the card, and the system will create the card for you. We ensure that the user is in control by first showing a preview of the card, allowing the user to either confirm, or rephrase the request. Figure 9 shows the kind of text you can use, and figure 10 gives you an idea of the interaction flow.

Figure 9: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards, showing an example prompt and the resulting card. Alt Text: a popover “Add Insights Cards” above My Home is shown, with a text entry field on the left containing the AI prompt “create a card showing sales orders in overall status open and delivery block status blocked with fields sold-to-party, requested delivery date and net value”, below that an AI “Generate” and a “Clear all” button, below that some sample queries, on the right the card preview showing “Open Sales Orders” with sub-title “With Delivery Block”.

 

Figure 10: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards in action. Alt Text: a short video showing the prompt from Figure 9 being entered, and the card being generated and added to the Insights section of My Home.

Watch the full video:

  • Video:  AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insights Cards in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  (0:54 min.)

AI-Assisted Financial Business Insights

Users in Finance now benefit from AI-generated analysis and summaries built into the following review booklets:

  • Cost Centers Review Booklet
  • Group Finanical Statements Review Booklet
  • Project Financial Booklet – Professional Services

Watch this video to get an overview for the cost centers review booklet:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Financial Business Insights (1:20 minutes)

Simplified Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI

With Joule and AI embedded in the applications, asset accountants can get their work done more easily now, with:

  • AI-assisted asset creation with Joule.
  • Easy to understand AI-generated natural language explanations of depreciation keys.
  • AI-generated value calculation insights.

Figure 11: AI-generated asset valuation explanation, after the user clicked on the AI-button “Explain Key Figures”. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a table summarizing the asset valuation, with an AI button “Explain Key Figures” in the table heading. Below the table a section “Explain Key Figures” is shown, with a text explaining how the depreciation is calculated.

Have a look at this video to see all three of these in action:

  • Video: Simplify Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3:25 minutes).

 

Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams

In addition to being able to process To Dos for tasks directly in Microsoft Teams (as I featured in my February blog post), you can now also process To Dos for Business Situations directly in Microsoft Teams.

This means that you get notified in your Teams activity feed about new Business Situations, and you can process Business Situations in place, without having to leave Teams, as you can see in Figure 12.

Figure 12: To Dos for Business Situations are available via Activities in Microsoft Teams. Alt Text: Two screenshots are shown, the top one shows an row of Situation cards in My Home, the bottom one shows the Activity view in Teams, with the activity “Situations in SAP S/4HANA” and sub-text “There are 9 situations for you” selected on the left, and the right two thirds of the screen showing a list with the same situations as shown in My Home.

To enable this, you need to install the SAP S/4HANA for Microsoft Teams app.

For further information:

  • Video: To Dos in Microsoft Teams (1:00)
  • Documentation: Integrating Microsoft Teams.

 

UX Improvements in Details

The details matter for a great user experience, so we continue to gather user feedback and work on improving these details, which though relatively small can have a big impact on user satisfaction. Let’s have a look at the highlights of what we are improving with the 2508 release.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time – magic!

Figure 13: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 13. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 14 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The “Threshold” determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the “Scroll Threshold” determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 14: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “Configure Table” with two new fields “Threshold”, being edited with the value 3000, and “Scroll Threshold”, containing the value 300.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 15, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry “1710 (BestRun US)”, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is “BestRun US”. In the popover “Sort By” section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 15: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over “Column Settings” with two sections “Sort By” and “Group By”. The “Sort By” section has two lines, “Company Code” and “Company Name”, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing “no sorting”, “ascending”, “descending”.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 16), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 16: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “View Settings” containing tabs “Columns”, “Sort”, “Filter”, and a pop-over “Filters” with two options “Hide descriptions” (selected) and “Hide Unselected” (deselected) . “Columns” is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is “Company Code”, followed by “Created On” – i.e. the description column “Company Name” is not listed next to the “Company Code”.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example “1710 (BestRun US)” as shown in Figure 15. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example “US Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)” as shown in Figure 1.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Table Grouping and/or “Show more per row” State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleage: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see they same grouping applied.

Similarly, if “show more per row” was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse – but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting “Keyboard Shortcuts” in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

entry.title: Re: Change SI Unit
entry.content:
To change the SI unit from KG to a newly created unit "1K" in SAP, you’ll need to follow a few key steps. However, it's important to note that SI units (Standard International Units) are predefined in SAP and cannot be changed directly. Instead, you can create a new unit of measure (UoM) and define conversion rules from the SI unit to your custom unit.

Go to Transaction Code CUNI, create a new unit "1K", define its dimension (e.g., weight), set the conversion factor from KG to 1K (e.g., 1K = 1000 KG or whatever your logic is). In CUNI, under the "Conversions" tab, set the numerator and denominator for conversion between KG and 1K. Example if 1K = 1000 KG, then Numerator = 1000 and Denominator = 1

entry.title: Re: How to decide "Do not post data in ERP" in /SCWM/ISU...
entry.content:
The functionality of Post to ERP (Do not tick “Do not post data in ERP”) is if you want the stock to be reflected in both EWM and ERP (Inventory Management). This is typical for initial stock uploads during go-live or data migration. The system will create material documents in ERP (e.g., movement type 561).

The functionality of Post Only in EWM (Tick “Do not post data in ERP”) is if you want to upload stock only in EWM, without affecting ERP. Useful for testing, simulation, or temporary decoupling of systems. ERP will not reflect the stock, but will reflect only in EWM.

So the decision to post inventory data in ERP (ECC or S/4HANA) or only in EWM depends on your business scenario and system setup.

entry.title: Re: Shared Resource Scenario in PPDS
entry.content:
Hi @Debasis_Nanda 

Thank you for the details.

Evaluating from your details that your packing line runs for 8 hours per order, but your shared resource is modelled with a 24-hour capacity shows a mismatch. I believe this mismatch is due to the way the shared resource’s bucket capacity and consumption duration are defined.

Consider defining the usage of the shared resource per operation with a duration that matches the packing activity in your PDS. This means the hopper resource will only be "blocked" for those 8 hours per operation, not for the full 24 hours. You can do this by assigning the duration-based usage in the secondary resource tab of the operation. This should not just be the quantity but also the time window they are required.

Please also make sure you activate finite scheduling on both primary and secondary resources so that the system respects the capacity constraints properly across packing lines.

If your packing rates differ per product, consider modelling this using PDS variants or setup groups, so each product gets the appropriate hopper consumption and duration without hardcoding it.

I hope this helps.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: EWM Replenishment with HU Types and Packing Step – Er...
entry.content:
Ensure your POSC configuration includes an intermediate storage type (e.g., packing station) before the final destination bin. In customizing: SCM Extended Warehouse Management → Cross-Process Settings → Storage Control → Define Process-Oriented Storage Control. There define a storage process with steps like Remove from stock, Pack (intermediate storage type: packing workstation), Put away. This ensures the system routes the HU first to the packing station, and delays final bin validation until after repacking.

In the storage type configuration for the fixed bin go to SCM EWM → Master Data → Define Storage Type. Under Putaway Control, check HU Type Check is set to blank or allow broader HU types, Putaway Storage Control is enabled to defer bin validation until after POSC steps. This allows the system to create the initial WT without failing due to HU type mismatch.

SAP Note 2409948 recommends this BAdI /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_NBIN_NRM for similar mixed storage scenarios. You can programmatically bypass HU type validation during initial WT creation if POSC is active

SAP Best Practice is

  • Use Document Info Records (DIRs) to attach BoQ documents to WBS.
  • Maintain BoQ versions for change tracking.
  • Integrate with SAP MM and SAP SD for full procurement and billing flows.

entry.title: Why we created Open Resource Discovery
entry.content:
What is Open Resource Discovery?

Open Resource Discovery (ORD) is a protocol for application / service metadata publishing and discovery. It can be used as a foundation for metadata catalogs / marketplaces and runtime introspection of system landscape resources. For more information, have a look at the ORD Introduction.

Building a static API & Event Catalog

The origin of ORD was as a publishing channel to SAP Business Accelerator Hub - formerly known as SAP API Hub - the centralized catalog for the public APIs and events offered by SAP products and SAP’s partners.

SAP aspires to offer one central place where developers can browse and explore existing APIs and get the API contracts as opposed to a proliferation of disconnected API portals and catalogs per product. From the beginning, we needed to support multiple protocols like OData, plain REST and SOAP. Early in this project, we established the use of open industry standards, most notably OpenAPI as the common denominator to describe all REST-based APIs (incl. OData).

When putting many different protocols and metadata description formats into one catalog, it quickly becomes obvious that the catalog needs some reliably consistent information across them:

  • Description: Titles, (short) descriptions, links, tags, etc.
  • Lifecycle: Version, lifecycle status and timelines (beta, active, deprecated), successors for deprecated, changelog, etc.
  • Taxonomy: Assignment to vendors, products, industry taxonomy, etc.
  • Grouping: Which resources belong together, can be discovered together

The second challenge was to provide an easy, automated way to publish the API & Event metadata, including the shared information listed above.

In 2018-2019, this led to the first drafts of the ORD protocol, driven by the Business Accelerator Hub team. The idea was to define a Service Provider Interface (SPI) enabling applications to expose their metadata by describing themselves, as an application is the only reliable source of information about itself. ORD is entirely complementary to the metadata industry standards we were already using; it merely provides a discovery wrapper around them and adds some common shared information, taxonomy, and relationships to build a single catalog from many individual sources.

With the ORD API implemented, an application can now register itself on Business Accelerator Hub and the metadata can be crawled and published without manual intervention, thus streamlining the publishing process.

Understanding Customer System Landscapes (Runtime Introspection)

In 2020, the Open Resource Discovery specification moved ownership to SAP’s Cross-Product Alignment (CPA) team. We quickly realized the potential in this idea, also beyond publishing static metadata to Business Accelerator Hub.

In the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), we needed a better understanding of the runtime (customer) system landscapes, including API and event resources. Since many of SAP’s larger solutions are highly customizable and extensible, the challenge is that each tenant can be different: some APIs may not be activated, some may have field extensions, some may have been added by the customer. Since the metadata in Business Accelerator Hub is static, it can only document a generic baseline of what a customer could look like. To find out what has changed since the snapshot taken in Business Accelerator Hub, it has become necessary to inspect the metadata of the systems at runtime.

This runtime metadata can be very useful – for example, when creating side-by-side extensions in BTP or SAP Build, the developers benefit from knowing the actual state of interfaces, so they can find them more quickly and safely build against them

We realized that the same protocol and interfaces can be used to do both: describe the static baseline metadata and its current state. Therefore, we generalized the ORD specification to work for both static and runtime metadata discovery and integrate it with the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL).

When generalizing the ORD standard, we defined some design goals – one of which was that the standard should work not only for SAP but be more general-purpose, so that it can be adopted and used by other companies once we open-sourced it. After verifying that ORD works well in SAP production environments, we released v1.0 to general availability in 2021.

Support Adoption and Validation with Tooling

Developers and integrations rely on machine-readable, well documented API interfaces. To improve the overall experience, we need to ensure that we have 1) wide coverage of metadata existing resources and 2) decent quality, so that API metadata is useful, consistent, and reliable for human developers and machines alike.

To scale this across a large company like SAP, it’s essential to not only provide guidelines and specs – we also need to make it easy to adopt the metadata approach and have a quick validation / feedback loop.

For the ease of adoption, the obvious solution is to build ORD support right into the frameworks, like the ABAP Platform or the CAP Framework and provide a generic provider server to easily provide static metadata.

The quality and validation aspect turned out to be a big topic of its own – we invested in creating a metadata validator that can not only validate ORD, but also the most important metadata formats we transport along inside of it. Quality is also a gradual and moving goal, so we created a concept of “policy levels” in which we distinguish between various degrees or goals of quality – and can validate which level the published content has achieved.

To increase the quality of the metadata, we realized that we need to come to the validation step early in the process (“shift left”), so we don’t identify issues too late, in the worst case not before publishing. Validation ideally happens in the CI/CD of the local application development. The central publishing targets then act as quality gates to ensure at least a baseline for quality. Therefore, we made sure that our validation runs in the central quality gates and at the same time made it easy for product teams to run the same validations locally.

By continuously validating already published metadata according to old and new rules, we have a data-driven approach to identify where we need to increase quality and which validation rules are realistic to enforce. With this loop, we were already able to improve the metadata and documentation quality of SAP software and can grow it continuously.

Integrating Data Products into ORD

In 2022-2023, when we started the work on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the Data Mesh and Data Product topic become very relevant to us as a company. We quickly realized the potential of reusing the ORD specification and the infrastructure for metadata discovery, validation, and cataloging. Even better, by integrating data products into ORD, we were able to ensure that data products are not a silo for data scientists but are interconnected with the existing, more developer-oriented concepts of APIs and Event

We enabled the description of Data Products in ORD to make them describable and discoverable just like other resources. For Data Products, some specialized API protocols like Delta Sharing became relevant to add. At this stage, we also had to extend ORD to describe integration dependencies to indicate input ports (potential data lineage) and we further invested into connecting all ORD concepts with business and domain concepts, like Business Objects (Entity Types). For more background, have a look at the blog post: The Metadata behind SAP Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud.

We have now started to connect APIs, Events, and Data Products to business processes, as this connects the concepts of various personas (developers, data scientists, business experts). By interlinking the concepts, we help discovery, search and make it easier to understand what belongs together.

Extend with AI and Knowledge Graph

We are currently seeing a rise in specialized AI agent protocols like MCP and A2A. With this comes a need to build registries / catalogs so consumers or agents can discover them. From the ORD perspective, agent or tools are just a special  type of API protocol we could put in the same API catalog - just like Delta Sharing was a new API Protocol geared towards Data Products.

Current efforts on MCP and A2A seem to solve the discovery problem for a single protocol in isolation. However, we see value in having a combined catalog that can include both MCP and A2A – and it is likely there will be more agent protocols to follow.

AI agents will benefit from knowledge graphs for further grounding, for helping to avoid AI hallucinations, for storing knowledge explicitly, to reduce the cost and compute of agentic planning, and to provide explain-ability of reasoning. Building an MCP API / proxy around every existing API is costly, so we see potential in bringing in the huge, existing ecosystem of APIs, Events, and Data Products into knowledge graphs. We also see value in having AI to assist with understanding often very complex, customized system landscapes and what they offer, how they can be integrated, and extended.

Establishing ORD as a Linux Foundation Standard

In 2023, ORD was released as an SAP open-source standard, accessible for industry-wide adoption. In 2025 we changed ORD's ownership model, contributing it to the Linux Foundation via the publicly funded ApeiroRA / IPCEI-CIS program. With this we ensure vendor-neutral governance and long-term independence from SAP. The standard is now open to contributions and ownership of other companies as well. Thus, ORD has laid the foundation to potentially become an accepted industry standard. ORD received the 2025 API award in the category “Best in API standards and specification”.

Our Vision

We believe that we have created something special with ORD: We are not aware of any stable, open-source standard that can handle the metadata discovery of applications / services across different protocols and types of resources, tailored to the requirements of various personas and products. There are a few projects with similar goals – some redundant, some complementary – as ORD. A detailed comparison would require at least one more blog post, which may come at a different time.

Many years of SAP experience across multiple products, use cases, and stakeholders went into the standard. With ORD, it’s possible to break up metadata silos and create a well-connected metadata graph of the technical resources in your IT landscape.

We believe that a good metadata integration architecture is an important pillar to achieve transparency in a well-integrated IT landscape and benefits developers, applications and AI alike.

If you have questions, feedback, or interest in collaboration, feel free to create a GitHub issue or reach out to Simon Heimler directly. We are looking forward to collaborating with other companies on the future of ORD. Collaboration with the Technical Steering Committee is very welcome.

entry.title: Re: View's field is empty although it isn't empty in its...
entry.content:
If your Z-table is meant to store language-dependent texts (like descriptions), and SPRAS is part of the key, SAP expects a text table relationship. If this isn’t defined properly, the maintenance view might not display the language field correctly. To fix this, go to SE11 → your Z-table → Extras → Language-Dependent Texts. Define the text table relationship properly. Ensure SPRAS is marked as a key field in the text table

If your maintenance view is joining multiple tables (e.g., a base table and a text table), and SPRAS is part of the key, the join condition must explicitly include SPRAS. To fix this, check in SE11 → maintenance view → check the Join Conditions. Make sure SPRAS is included in the join between base and text table. Without this, the system might not be able to match the correct language entry.

If the Z-table is not set up correctly as a text table, SAP might not treat SPRAS as a language key in views. To fix this, go to SE11 → Z-table → check Delivery Class. For text tables, use A (Application Table) or L (Text Table). Also check Table Category; it should be Transparent Table

entry.title: Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release
entry.content:
Keeping business users informed about system and company news is essential for organizational success. When users are aware of changes that could impact their daily tasks, they can make better decisions, adapt more quickly, and boost overall productivity. Staying up to date—especially with updates on processes, departments, or system changes—helps eliminate confusion and ensures alignment across teams.  

While our existing news feed provides valuable updates on SAP system changes, we’ve listened closely to customer feedback and enhanced communication and user experience on My Home even further. In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, we now offer the ability to customize and manage the My Home news feed through the new Manage News application.

Manage News Application

 

Introducing the Manage News Application 

The Manage News application empowers news administrators to deliver timely, targeted information updates directly to business users via a centralized news feed. 

Key capabilities for news administrators include: 

  • Create, manage, and publish news articles: Administrators can compose news posts to be displayed on My Home, controlling the flow of critical company and system updates. 
  • Control visibility and importance: News items can be marked as critical, ensuring essential information is highlighted and receives appropriate attention from business users. 
  • Plan and schedule communications: Administrators can organize when specific news should be published, enabling timely and organized delivery of updates. 
  • Language adaptation: Messages can be tailored in all company-supported languages, ensuring effective communication across diverse user groups. 
  • Targeted audience assignment: News can be assigned to specific App Transaction codes, so only users with access to the corresponding Fiori apps or transaction codes will see relevant news items. 
  • Organize news by groups or categories: News articles can be grouped into categories such as Finance or Human Resources, making it easy for users to find pertinent information. 
  • Visual enhancements: Administrators can upload images aligned with news topics to make posts more engaging and visually informative. 

News article creation in Manage News Application

 

What Business Users Will Experience 

The My Home news feed now displays articles created by news administrators, neatly organized into designated categories. Critical updates are clearly marked with an eye-catching critical marker to ensure users notice and prioritize these messages. 

This personalized news feature centralizes essential communications in one place, tailored to the needs of each user based on their system app access. By delivering relevant, timely information directly to business users, organizations can foster a more informed and agile workforce. 

 Critical News displayed in My Home News Feed 

Critical News Article in My Home News dialog

 

Benefits for Your Organization 

With the Manage News application, administrators can tailor the news feed to reflect the specific needs of your company or organization, enabling more effective communication with business users. This streamlined and targeted approach to information sharing helps: 

  • Improve user awareness and decision-making 
  • Minimize confusion and misalignment across teams 
  • Increase adaptability to system or process changes 
  • Enhance overall company performance 

 

Prerequisites 

To access the Manage News application users or administrators will have to be assigned to the SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_MNG_PC business catalogue. For business users to view the news feed on My Home they will have to be assigned SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC catalogue. The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE role will already have SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC business catalogue assigned. With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, news maintained in the Manage News application will be displayed by default for all customers who have not configured a RSS feed or SAP Custom System News. To display the news from the Manage News application the 'Manage News App' setting needs to be enabled via UI Adaptation mode (Adapt UI in the User Actions menu). Users or administrator must have the catalog SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLEX attached to their role to access the UI Adaptation key user capabilities. 

My Home UI Adaptation Mode News Feed Settings

 

We’re excited to bring this powerful new communication feature to you with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release and look forward to seeing how it helps your business stay connected and informed. 

If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality.

If you share more about your development goals and environment, the community can provide more tailored recommendations!

entry.title: Currency and unit conversion in SAP Datasphere Analytic Model with variable and value help
entry.content:
Currency conversion is the act of changing financial information from one currency into another. This process is especially crucial for global businesses that conduct operations across various countries and handle transactions in multiple currencies.

Unit conversion is also important because it ensures consistency, accuracy, and clarity when working with different measurement systems. Unit conversion enables accurate, effective communication and operations across systems, industries, and borders.

The following steps are carried out for currency / unit conversion in SAP Datasphere:

1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

4. Create input parameters with input help

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

For currency conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • TCURV - Exchange rate types
  • TCURW - Exchange rate type text
  • TCURX - Decimal places in currencies
  • TCURN - Quotations
  • TCURR - Exchange rates
  • TCURF - Conversion factors
  • TCURC - Currency codes
  • TCURT - Currency text

For unit conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • T006 - Units of Measurement
  • T006D - Dimensions
  • T006A - Assign Internal to Language-Dependent Unit

    1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

a) Start the creation of the corresponding tables and views in the correct space in the Data Builder via Create and Currency / Unit Conversion Views

b) Choose source system and check objects. 

c) After clicking on “Create”, all objects are created automatically.

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

Create a task chain and include all relevant data flows to upload data into the required tables. To keep the data up to date, it is advisable to schedule the task chain.

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

In the fact view, which is located under the analytical model, you must maintain the semantic types of the key figures and the associated units. Conversion in the analytical model can only take place through this step.

4. Create input parameters with input help

If the user is to be provided with a value aid when calling up variables, one or more input parameters must be created in the fact view.

If you only want to provide users with a narrow list with a few units, you can build a view on the unit table and enter it here as value help. You can also set a default value here.

Attention: You may have to set the field length of WAERS to 3 in the view.

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

a) You can now create conversion measures in the analytical model.

b) Enter business name and technical name for your new measure. Select source measure. SAP Datasphere uses the source key figure to recognize whether a unit or currency conversion needs to be carried out.

c) Select the date to which you want to convert and the appropriate exchange rate type (only for currency translation). Then click on the selection help for Target Currency and select “Variable”.

Click on "Use existing Source Variable" and choose the correct one.

d) Under “Advanced”, select the client that is maintained in the TCURR table and what should happen if an error occurs.

TCURR:

e) Go back to main Analytic Model Properties and check error messages or test the new measure in preview.

Tip:

If the analytical model existed before the input parameters were created in the fact view below, they must be mapped manually to new or existing variables.

 

Conclusion

Currency and unit conversions are foundational components in ensuring data integrity, consistency, and meaningful analysis in multinational environments. SAP Datasphere offers a structured and streamlined approach to managing these conversions by leveraging integrated tables from SAP S/4HANA and guided steps within the Data Builder and analytical model.

By systematically creating conversion views, automating data flows through task chains, assigning semantic types, configuring input parameters, and defining conversion measures, users can implement robust, scalable conversion logic. This ensures that financial and operational data across diverse units and currencies are harmonized and ready for accurate reporting and decision-making.

entry.title: cTMS Setup for SAP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
cTMS Architecture – SAP Build Work Zone

Here we have four environments Dev, QA, UAT, and Prod, each corresponding to a separate BTP subaccount. We have provisioned the Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) in a separate subaccount. The development team develops their content and export the same from the Dev subaccount using Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS), which then adds the transport to the QA node. From there, it is imported into QA and the subsequent environments (UAT, Prod) through Solution Manager (SolMan), leveraging Focused Build (FB) or Charm status transitions.

Additionally, this setup can be integrated with SAP Cloud ALM

Setup Steps:

Since several of these SaaS applications share common setup steps, please begin by following the initial setup steps outlined here Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Step1: Create Service Instance for SAP Build Work Zone

We need to subscribe to SAP Build work zone, standard edition, with Application Plan, which you might have already subscribed when you are setting up SAP Build Work Zone. 

Here are the plans available, for cTMS setup, we need a service instance and key as well for setting up destinations to target subaccount for moving the transports. 

For creating Service Instance/key, you should already setup a space in your Cloud Foundry, if you did not setup yet. 

Navigate to corresponding space and create the Service Instance, chose the SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition and chose the standard plan, then create the Service Key. 

Note: you need to do this in all subaccounts including Dev. 

 

Step2: Create Destination to cTMS

We need to setup a destination with name "ctms_destination" in source subaccount, this is required for integrating with cTMS.

Name: should be "ctms_destination"

URL: uri found in the cTMS service key

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: uaa → url from the cTMS service key 

Please use Client ID & Secret from cTMS Service Key. 

Step3: Create Destinations to CF Subaccounts

In the subaccount where the Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) service is subscribed, create a destination to each target SAP Build Work Zone subaccount. 

Name: Give appropriate name to resemble your CTMS Node

URL:https://portal-service.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/cdm_import_service

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com

Please use the client id, secret, from the SAP Build Work Zone service key created in step1 above. 

Step4: Configure Transport Nodes in cTMS

Prerequisites

  • You have been assigned one of the following roles: Administrator or LandscapeOperator.

From the cTMS UI, you can define transport nodes to represent your system landscape. There are multiple ways to create a node:

You can either Create a node on the Landscape Visualization screen or from Transport Nodes screen. 

Allow Upload to Node: Enable this checkbox to allow file uploads to the node. Enabled for the Dev node only. 

Forward Mode: Default value is Auto, You can change this setting based on your landscape and transport flow requirements.

Controlled by SAP Solution Manager: Select this checkbox only if you plan to integrate with SAP Solution Manager (e.g., Charm or Focused Build). We will only enable this for QA and upper environments.  When you enable this, it will not allow manual imports from cTMS UI, only through Charm/FB status change. 

Note: If you plan to integrate with Cloud ALM, do not check this option. 

Content Type: For SAP BWZ, select Application Content.

Destination: Select the appropriate target destination you previously configured in your cTMS subaccount in Step3.

Step5: Create Transport routes in cTMS

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

Name: Provide the appropriate name

Chose the Source node & Target node and click on OK. 

After setting up Transport Nodes and routes, your landscape looks something like this based on the number of environments you have. 

Note: You can also use Transport Landscape Wizard, with which you can setup the all your landscape nodes & routes at a time.

Step6: Integrate with Solution Manager

To integrate Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) with SAP Solution Manager (Charm / Focused Build), follow the step6 from below article. 

If you want to integrate with Cloud ALM, follow the step7 from below article. 

 Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Conclusion:

I hope you learned, how to setup cTMS for SAP Build Work Zone. Now the setup is complete and ready for transporting the content using cTMS either integrated with SAP Solution Manager or Cloud ALM.

Thank you for reading  my article, feel free to provide any feedback or comment for any questions.

Thanks,
Raghu

Dear Prinya,
CJ20N itself is not part of compatibility packages, but only some sub-feature of CJ20N, such as hierachy graphics and others. Unfortunately, it is not possible to exactly check for the usage of these sub-features.
Therefore, we decided for CJ20N and similar other cases to check for the main transactions as indicator for possible feature usage in our tools such as Early Watch and Simplification Item Check even if these leads to false positives.
Generally, the outcome of these reports should be considered as indicators for compatibility package usage that must be double-checked with the affected business departments.
